head.title: Global Warming: A Will to Act?

hedline.hl1: Global Warming: A Will to Act?

abstract.p: Prof Michael Oppenheimer letter, commenting on April 23 article on global warming, says clearest distinction between US and other countries regarding global warming is quality of national political leadership

block.p: ''Yelling 'Fire' on a Hot Planet'' (Week in Review, April 23) argues that American attitudes toward global warming present a nearly insurmountable obstacle to action.

But survey research finds no substantial difference between the level of concern about global warming in the United States compared with other countries, including Britain, the Netherlands and Germany, which have carried out the Kyoto Protocol and are reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
''Yelling 'Fire' on a Hot Planet'' (Week in Review, April 23) argues that American attitudes toward global warming present a nearly insurmountable obstacle to action.

But survey research finds no substantial difference between the level of concern about global warming in the United States compared with other countries, including Britain, the Netherlands and Germany, which have carried out the Kyoto Protocol and are reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

The clearest distinction between the United States and these countries is the quality of political leadership at the national level. The Bush administration has denied the scientific consensus on global warming while intimidating its own researchers and touting domestic policies that have no effect on emissions.

Nevertheless, action to curb emissions is burgeoning at the local and state level, where mayors and governors, less beholden to the fossil-fuel lobby, are responding to public concern with leadership and foresight.
The writer is a professor of geosciences and international affairs at Princeton University.
